sexherodino asks "So I saw a picture saying
that bananas share 50% of their DNA with humans.
Is this true?"

Yeah, it's kind of true, but probably not
in the way that you think.

We know that DNA is made of four different
letters or bases, so at any two positions

between two genomes there's just a random
25% chance that they'll be the same.

Now as we look at longer and longer sequences,
that chance gets smaller, but it's still not
zero.

Still, we do share some segments of our genome
with the banana, because, well, many of the

basic mechanisms of life have been conserved
even between two distantly related species,

like DNA replication machinery, or mitochondrial
metabolism.

These are things that basically every eukaryote
shares.
50% really isn't that much.

I mean, we share more than 98% of our genome
with chimpanzees and look how different we
are from them.

I know it's an a-peeling thought, but just
comparing percentages of similarity between
two genomes doesn't tell us much.

It's just one small piece of the banana cream
pie that is genetics.

It's more about the proteins that they make
and the tiny amino acid variations between
them, and when and where they express them.
50% is really quite the SPLIT.

meisterj asks "Why does hearing or being around
someone throwing up make someone else feel
queasy or throw up?"
This is called "sympathetic vomiting".
Congratulations!
You have sympathy when it comes to vomiting.
I'm sure we've all been there, right?

Maybe your friend has one too many tequila
shots or a vicious stomach bug or goes a little

too hardcore at the local country fair pie-eating
contest.

All of a sudden their body decides that lunch
would be a little bit better out in the fresh
air.

So you catch a whiff of that, or for some
people if you even hear it, then your body
decides that it wants to join the party.

An area of your brain, the vomit control center
called the area postrema takes over, and well,
the vomity cycle begins.

Biologists think that this could be an evolutionary
adaptation that extends all the way back to
the earliest social apes.

Early humans would probably eat anything once,
but they didn't have a very good way of knowing
what was poisonous and what wasn't.

So if somebody from your social group eats
something and then throws it up, that's a
good sign that you don't want to eat that.

It could have been a survival technique to
blow chunks and live another day.

Humans might actually be the only ones who
do this.
Dogs, for instance, do the opposite.

If one of them vomits, then the other ones
will just eat it, and continue the cycle on
down the line.

soup-is-ready asks "Do you consider the term
LUCA correct?"

LUCA stands for Last Universal Common Ancestor
which is a theoretical organism that is the

shared ancestor of all life on Earth, from
bacteria to beavers.

It's also known as just "LUA" or "MRCA" for
most recent common ancestor.

Our earliest evidence for life on Earth as
we know it now is 3.7 billion year old deposits

found in Greenland, or these 3.5 billion year
old microbial mats that were discovered in
Australia.

But all life coming from one organism isn't
the only way we could have hypothetically
gotten here.

We could have had multiple ancestors swapping
genes or leading to different domains of life
back there in the primordial ooze.

But, biologists who have modeled these scenarios
say that it is 10 to the 2,860 times more

likely that we all evolved from one single
common ancestor rather than multiple ones.

But that doesn't mean that our ancestor was
the only life form alive back then, it just

means that all the other ones died out, which
is kinda sad, because it makes me wonder what
other amazing life could have been out there?
Bummer.

@SciencEric asks "Why is the speed limit of
the universe "c" and why is my ISP so good
at slowing this number down?"

According to Isaac Asimov, the abbreviation
"c" for the speed of light in a vacuum comes

from the latin world "celeritas", but he never
said where he got that from, so we have to
dig a little deeper.

"c" is most famous for being used by Einstein
in his famous equation e=mc^2 but its origin

actually goes back all the way to 1856 used
as an abbreviation for the speed of light.

But many pother physicists like James Clerk
Maxwell were using an upper-case V for the

speed of light, and even Einstein used this
until 1907.

We also know that going back as far as Newton
and Galileo, as was the custom things were

written in Latin, so "celeritas" was used
as sort of a generic term for speed, just
not in the relation to light.

There's also a chance it just stands for "constant"
which is pretty boring.

Either way, once Einstein the patent clerk
became Einstein the superstar physicist of

relativity, everyone started using "c", for
copycat.
As for your ISP?

Sorry man, there are some problems even Einstein
can't solve.
